It includes provisions for civil remedies for copyright owners injured by violations, allowing them to bring civil actions in court. In civil actions under the "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004," the court has the discretion to grant injunctions, impound articles involved in violations, and award damages to the injured party. The court may award attorney fees, costs, actual damages, additional profits, or statutory damages to the injured party in civil actions under the "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004." The court may award actual damages to the injured party for violations of intellectual property rights, including profits of the violator not accounted for in the damages calculation. The court may award actual damages for violations of intellectual property rights, including counterfeit labels or packaging on phonorecords or works of visual art. The value of the copyrighted material is determined by the presence of counterfeit documentation. The value of a phonorecord, copy, or work of visual art is determined by the retail value of an authorized copy of the copyrighted material, such as sound recordings, musical works, computer programs, motion pictures, audiovisual works, and literary works. The retail value of authorized copies of copyrighted material, including sound recordings, musical works, computer programs, motion pictures, audiovisual works, literary works, pictorial, graphic, sculptural works, and works of visual art, is used to determine damages in copyright infringement cases. The injured party can choose to receive statutory damages of at least $2,500 per violation instead of actual damages and profits. The court may award statutory damages of $2,500 to $25,000 for each violation of copyright infringement. The court can triple the damages for subsequent violations within 3 years of a previous judgment. A civil action must be filed within 3 years of the violation. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, and do not apply to electronic transmissions of specific documents described in Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect fair use under Title 17, United States Code, for genuine certificates, licensing documents, registration cards, labeling components, or documentation described in Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect fair use for labeling components, documentation, or packaging described in section 2318(b) of title 18, United States Code. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the ``Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act''.

SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946. Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection (e) stating that in cases of violation, it will be presumed willful if false contact information was knowingly provided. The new subsection (e) of Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 presumes willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering, maintaining, or renewing a domain name for a violation. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. The registration authority must verify accurate contact information when registering a domain name to prevent willful infringement. The term 'domain name' is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of a felony offense involving the false registration and use of a domain name. The maximum imprisonment for the offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less. The term "falsely registers" is defined as registering in a way that hinders identification or contact with the registrant. The term "falsely registers" is defined as registering in a way that hinders identification or contact with the registrant. The term "domain name" is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines to deter online felony offenses facilitated by domain names with false contact information. The Sentencing Commission will enhance sentences for felony offenses involving false contact information provided to domain name authorities. The Sentencing Commission will increase penalties for felony offenses related to false contact information provided to domain name authorities, as defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205 of the legislation clarifies that it does not affect free speech or press rights related to domain name activities, does not limit court discretion in determining damages for intellectual property infringement, and does not restrict courts in determining imprisonment terms for offenses. TITLE III--COURTS

SEC. 301. ADDITIONAL PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE DISTRICT OF COLORADO.

Section 85 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Colorado Springs," after "Boulder,".

SEC. 302. PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK.

Section 112(a) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Plattsburgh," after "Malone,".
